subject: Creativity
title: Brainstorming Is Broken: Why Groups Kill Ideas
description: A quick, practical guide to Brainstorming Is Broken: Why Groups Kill Ideas.

hook.text: Alex Osborn invented brainstorming in 1953, promising it would double creative output.

buildup.text: Groups brainstorming together produce fewer AND lower-quality ideas than the same number of people working.

discovery.text: Three killers: production blocking (waiting your turn), evaluation apprehension (fear of judgment), and social loafing.

twist.text: The fix: 'brainwriting.' Everyone writes ideas silently, then shares them.

climax.text: Amazon's Jeff Bezos banned brainstorming meetings. Instead, everyone writes a six-page memo read silently.

punchline.text: Brainstorming feels creative. Working alone actually IS creative.

quiz.question: Why does traditional brainstorming produce fewer ideas than individual work?
options: Production blocking, evaluation apprehension, and social loafing
